Award.AwardTitle: Travel Grant for Grand Challenges of Traceability (GCT): The Next Ten Years

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This travel grant will fund participants to attend a workshop entitled "Grand Challenges of Traceability (GCT): The Next Ten Years. The travel support will give priority to students, underrepresented groups, and those in need of funds not otherwise available. The purpose of the workshop is to reflect on the past decade of research on software traceability and to develop a research agenda for the next decade. The meeting will take place in Kentucky in March of 2017. The intellectual merit is to advance research and practice in software traceability, which instruments software development processes with links between software development artifacts, automatically computing links and empowering software tools to assist software developers. The broader impacts are to improve the maintainability and evolvability of software systems and to help build the community of researchers who address these problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this travel grant is to fund participants to attend the workshop on 'Grand Challenges of Traceability (GCT): The Next Ten Years', held in Slade, KY, USA, March 31-April 1, 2017 (http://gct10.soccerlab.polymtl.ca/). The two-day event brought more than 30 researchers and practitioners of software and systems traceability throughout the world and discussed what had been achieved and what is still ahead. The intellectual merit is to advance research and practice in software traceability, which instruments software development processes with links between software development artifacts, automatically computing links and empowering software tools to assist software developers. The broader impacts are to improve the maintainability and evolvability of software systems and to help build the community of researchers who address these problems.

The travel grant helped attract and support the next generation of junior faculty and student participants (especially the US-based participants from underrepresented groups) to build a competent and advanced workforce of software and systems developers. The sixteen (16) awardees actively participated in the two-day GCT-10 event on different research, education, training, and mentoring activities such as paper presentations, group discussions, chairing sessions, judging posters, laying out research roadmaps and agenda, contributing to the post-event proceedings, etc. The specific objective of supporting people from underrepresented groups was achieved by awarding ten (10) female, one (1) Latino, and one (1) African American participants. Among the sixteen (16) awardees, fourteen (14) were first-time participants of the series of GCT/SST/TEFSE events focusing on software and systems traceability, showing the professional development initiatives and opportunities made possible by the travel grant. A few awardees who were Master's students stated specifically that GCT-10 helped shape their views of academia in general and pursuing their Ph.D. degrees in particular. The post-event proceedings (https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.03129) contained contributions from fifteen (15) out of sixteen awardees.
